description: Borrowed from Middle French imputer, from Latin imputō (“to bring into the reckoning, charge, impute”).

verbs.description: impute (third-person singular simple present imputes, present participle imputing, simple past and past participle imputed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To attribute or ascribe (responsibility or fault) to a cause or source.
examples: The teacher imputed the student's failure to his nervousness.

entries.meaning: (transitive, theology) To ascribe (sin or righteousness) to someone by substitution.

examples: People impute great cleverness to cats.

entries.meaning: (transitive, statistics) To replace missing data with substituted values.
